The same study found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls (Action 732). For training interventions, a randomised, replicated, controlled study in Norway found higher survival rates in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis if they had undergone aerobic training, with interval training being more effective than continuous training (Action 740). Additionally, vaccination studies provide supporting evidence, with two controlled studies from Iceland and Norway finding higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups post exposure to disease-causing bacteria Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri, respectively (Action 733).
summary_statements: The evidence shows that probiotics, immunostimulants, and specific training methods can improve salmon survival against diseases.
One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28 day period compared with controls.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway found the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when the salmon were fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway found that adding beta-glucans to a salmon diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
A study in Norway found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved salmon gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls.
A randomised, replicated, controlled study in Norway found higher survival rates in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis if the salmon had undergone aerobic training.
The same study in Norway found that for salmon survival against infectious pancreatic necrosis, interval training was more effective than continuous training.

A controlled study from Iceland found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups after exposure to the disease-causing bacteria Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes.
A controlled study from Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups after exposure to the disease-causing bacteria Yersinia ruckeri.

question_details.query: Based on studies in Australia, which husbandry practices have shown mixed or limited success in managing diseases and environmental impacts from salmon farming?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on studies in Australia, several husbandry practices have shown mixed or limited success in managing diseases and environmental impacts from salmon farming. Freshwater bathing has provided mixed evidence for reducing amoebic gill disease, with one study in Australia finding a reduction in numbers of amoebae on salmon gills persisting for up to 10 days after bathing, while another replicated, controlled study found similar levels of amoebae in the gills of treated and untreated salmon (Action 739). Fallowing systems showed limited effectiveness for disease management, as one study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used (Action 1026). However, fallowing did show some success for pollution reduction, with a trial in Tasmania finding sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non-impacted sites over two fallowing cycles (Action 1027). Altering cage size showed positive results, with a replicated study in Australia recording lower levels of amoebic gill disease in salmon kept within larger compared to smaller cages (Action 742).
summary_statements: Based on studies in Australia, several husbandry practices have shown mixed or limited success in managing diseases and environmental impacts from salmon farming.
Freshwater bathing has provided mixed evidence for reducing amoebic gill disease.
One study in Australia found a reduction in numbers of amoebae on salmon gills persisting for up to 10 days after freshwater bathing.
Another replicated, controlled study found similar levels of amoebae in the gills of treated and untreated salmon.
Fallowing systems showed limited effectiveness for disease management.
One study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used.
Fallowing did show some success for pollution reduction.
A trial in Tasmania found sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non-impacted sites over two fallowing cycles.
Altering cage size showed positive results.
A replicated study in Australia recorded lower levels of amoebic gill disease in salmon kept within larger compared to smaller cages.
